newsitem.title: HONG KONG: ASIAN DEBT MARKETS - HK firms go for bonds, loans.
newsitem.headline: ASIAN DEBT MARKETS - HK firms go for bonds, loans.

text.p: Hong Kong companies were in the Asian debt news on Friday.
Wharf Holdings has opted to tap U.S. investors with a Yankee bond, while other firms in the territory have taken the loan route.
Wharf Holdings began roadshowing its planned Yankee bond in Hong Kong. While details have not been set, bankers expect the bond to have a long maturity and perhaps two tranches.
There have been rumours for weeks that Wharf and other Hong Kong conglomerates would take advantage of a good market for Hong Kong and China credits in international markets.
Hong Kong and China bonds have performed extremely well in secondary markets over the last several months.
Hong Kong borrowers that have opted for the local loan markets also have found that their borrowing costs have declined substantially over the last year.
Cheung Kong and Kerry Holdings have loans in syndication, while Hysan has closed a loan-style floating rate note.
Bankers now say that New World Infrastructure, long tipped as a potential Yankee issuer, will borrow US$500 million through a loan issue arranged by HSBC Investment Bank Asia and Goldman Sachs.
Wheelock and Co also is taking the loan route. Bankers said the company is mulling a HK$3.0 billion deal. It has a maturity of three years extendible at the borrower's option to five.
The loan pays a margin of 50 basis points over the Hong Kong Interbank Offered Rate and an all-in return of 62.5 basis points to top tier participants.
ABN Amro, Chase Manhattan Asia and Hang Seng Bank are arrangers, bankers said.
Elsewhere, the Phillipines' Belle Corp launched a US$100 million floating rate note issue. Deutsche Morgan Grenfell is bookrunner. DMG and Hanwha Merchant Bank are joint leads.
The five-year, one-month FRN was launched at par to float at 180 basis points over the London Interbank Offered Rate. With fees, it pays an all-in return of 200 basis points.
